dhq:bio.p: Professor Carberry is a fictious person, born on a bulletin board in 1929. He is said to still teach at Brown University, and to be known for his work in "psychoceramics", the supposed study of cracked pots. He is also used by ORCID, Crossref, and now DHQ as a dummy account. His work has been published many times throughought in the intervening decades, most recently in the British Medical Journal in 2016.

dhq:authorInfo.dhq:affiliation: Association of the Friends of Jean-Baptiste Botul

dhq:bio.p: Jean-Baptiste Botul is a fictional French philosopher created in 1995 by the journalist Frédéric Pagès and other members of a group calling itself the Association of the Friends of Jean-Baptiste Botul. Originating as a literary hoax, the names of both Botul and his philosophy of botulism derive from botulism, an illness caused by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum. References to Botul were first made in publications by members of the association and later turned up in texts by writers who were not party to the hoax and thought Botul was a real person. There is now an annual Botul Prize awarded for a book that mentions Botul.

Mrs. Silence Dogood was the pen name used by Benjamin Franklin to get his work published in the New-England Courant, a newspaper founded and published by his brother James Franklin. She graciously translated this sample article from the original gibberish into English.

div.p: By nesting <div> elements within one another, articles are given a heirarchy of headings which get smaller with each use. DHQ's css creates four distinct font sizes for nested <div> elements when used properly.
This is actually a new <div>, but it uses a terminated <head> tag. By doing this, you can start a new section without a heading and still validate the document.

div.head: 2.1: Line Groups and Lines
div.p: An Ode to the Hamster (and an Example of Encoded Poetry)A semi-randomly generated sonnet from https://www.poem-generator.org.uk/sonnet/

lg.l: My tiny hamster, you inspire me to write.
I love the way you cuddle, squeak and skip,
Invading my mind day and through the night,
Always dreaming about the furry flip.
Let me compare you to a library?
You are more amazed, unfazed and superb.
Ice bites the debris of February,
And wintertime has the attractive blurb.
How do I love you? Let me count the ways.
I love your bold fingers, smile and eyebrows.
Thinking of your fuzzy smile fills my days.
My love for you is the inactive vows.
Now I must away with an active heart,
Remember my long words whilst we're apart.
